title: 109_s765
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Math and Science Incentive Act of 2005". Congress finds the United States needs a robust scientific and technical enterprise, more scientists and engineers, improved education in science and mathematics, and a recommitment to research and development. The United States needs to prioritize leadership in science, mathematics, and engineering, particularly in areas like nanotechnology. Implementing a loan forgiveness program to attract students to careers in these fields, including teaching, can help maintain technological leadership. Establishment of program for loan forgiveness to attract students to careers in science, mathematics, and engineering, including teaching. The Secretary will implement a program to cover interest on loans for undergraduate students who meet specific criteria outlined in the Act. The Act covers interest on loans for undergraduate students who meet specific criteria, including being a teacher of STEM subjects or a STEM professional, and committing to 5 years of service in that role. The Secretary will not pay interest that accrues before the repayment period begins on certain loans. The Secretary selects participants for the program based on national security, homeland security, and economic security needs of the United States, in consultation with various federal agencies. The Secretary selects participants for the program based on national security, homeland security, and economic security needs of the United States. Eligible applicants are chosen based on academic record, job performance, likelihood to complete service obligation, likelihood to remain in science, mathematics, or engineering, and other relevant criteria determined by the Secretary. Loan interest payments are subject to appropriations. The Secretary prioritizes interest payments for qualified applicants based on previous payments. Regulations may be prescribed to implement this section. Interest payments cover the period from agreement to loan repayment completion. The borrower's repayment period ends when:
- The loan is fully repaid
- The Secretary pays $10,000 on behalf of the borrower
- The borrower fails to fulfill the service obligation
- The borrower's income exceeds 4 times the national per capita income for 6 months The Secretary will repay the interest accrued on loans of selected student borrowers according to regulations. Eligible individuals must submit an application for loan interest payment, including an agreement to complete 5 consecutive years of service. If the individual fails to complete the required 5 consecutive years of service, they must repay the Secretary for any interest paid on their behalf. Consolidation loans may qualify for interest payment under certain conditions. Prevention of Double Benefits: Borrowers cannot receive benefits from both the Unsubsidized Stafford Loan program and certain other loan forgiveness programs for the same service. The Act defines terms such as "Secretary" and "mathematics, science, or engineering professional." It also authorizes appropriations for the Act for fiscal year 2006 and the following 5 years.
